article.headline: Nobody on the team had beaten the Illini
article.linkText: Northwestern beats Illinois for first time since '99
article.story: EVANSTON, Ill. (AP) -- When time finally expired, jubilant Northwestern fans flooded the court to celebrate a first for every player and coach on the Wildcats -- a victory over No. 25 Illinois. Reserve Davor Duvancic scored a career-high 22 points and Jitim Young had 15 points and 10 rebounds to lead Northwestern to the 70-60 win Wednesday night. It was Northwestern's first victory over Illinois in nearly 10 years. The Wildcats (7-7, 2-1 Big Ten) had lost eight straight to the Illini and 15 of their last 16. "Someone told me we hadn't won in a while. I know since I've been here, we haven't beaten Illinois," said Northwestern coach Bill Carmody, who was 0-5 against the Illini. "Illinois is one of the better teams in the conference. It's great." Duvancic scored 17 points in the second half, filling in for starter Vedran Vukusic who injured his knee in the first half. Illinois led 38-29 at halftime, but struggled to find good looks at the basket as Northwestern pulled away. The Illini shot 21 percent in the second half and were 2-of-20 from 3-point range. Northwestern went on a 15-5 run early in the half to take a 44-43 lead when Mohamed Hachad banked in a 3-pointer from the right side. Duvancic scored seven in a row during the run. Duvancic, guarded most of the night by 7-foot-2 center Nick Smith, forced Illinois to check him on the perimeter after hitting two 3s. He then used his quickness to drive around the slower Smith, going 7-of-10 from the field and 4-of-6 on 3s. "I said to myself, 'If I can't shoot it against him, I can't shoot the ball at all," Duvancic said. "It worked out good for me." And terribly for Illinois. Illinois (10-4, 1-2) dropped its second straight game and fell to 1-2 on the road. Illinois also shot 38 percent from the field for the second straight game. "If you're a Top 25 team you take care of business and you make shots when they make a run at you. We just didn't do it," Illinois coach Bruce Weber said. The game was tied at 52 when Young and Duvancic put Northwestern back on top -- this time for good. Young put back a miss by Parker, scored on a breakaway and made a twisting layup in traffic to give Northwestern a six-point lead. Duvancic then hit a 3 from the corner that bounced high off the front of the rim and dropped straight in for a 61-53 lead. "When that ball went all the way up and then down, I was like, 'Wow. This is my night," Duvancic said. T.J Parker added 13 points and five assists. Dee Brown had 19 points and James Augustine had 10 points and 14 rebounds for Illinois, which missed seven of 10 free throws over the final 6 minutes of the game. Northwestern trailed by 12 points early but went up 27-25 on a 3-pointer and layup by Vukusic. Later in the half, the Wildcats lost Vukusic when he came down awkwardly on his left leg going for a rebound. Vukusic, averaging 15 points a game, had to be helped off the court to the locker room and didn't return. Illinois led by as many as 12 points in the first half and took a 36-27 lead just before halftime when Brown made consecutive 3s, Augustine hit a short jump hook and Brown made another 3 from 2 feet beyond the arc as time expired. Brown, the Big Ten preseason player of the year, scored 14 points in the first half but was just 7-of-18 from the field. Even before the consecutive losses, Illinois had not been playing well. The Illini needed overtime to beat Illinois State two weeks ago, a game in which a frustrated Weber threw a chair at halftime. "Now it's a question of, do you hang together? Do you have character?" Weber said. "All of the things that I've been talking about that have plagued us, somehow we've got to find a way to change it."
